fields.description:
*Problem Description*
Based on the [Deleting a job's current working files|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Deleting+a+job%27s+current+working+files], you could find *Files* tab to delete the Job's working directory from Job Configuration page, as long as there are some files in the job working directory, and it's built using Local agent. However, despite the two conditions met, it won't generate the *Files* tab in Job's configuration. Generating artifacts from the job also didn't change anything.

Here's the screenshot after the job is successful and the conditions are met and with artifacts.
!filestabjob.png!

*Steps to replicate*
# Make sure you have Bamboo running on local agent
# You could put some artifact definition, and make sure that the build does not clear the working directory after the build is finished
# Run the plan build
# Check the job conifguration

*Workaround*
Delete the working files manually from {{$BAMBOO-HOME/xml-data/build-dir/$JOB-KEY}} or use *Force Clean build*
fields.summary: Unable to find the Files tab inside Job configuration

fields.description:
I need to specify a per-job directory for java.io.tmpdir by adding "-Djava.io.tmpdir=/path/to/tmp/${bamboo.buildKey\}" to the maven goal in my build, but when the job runs, it still uses a default java.io.tmpdir property:

{quote}
running command line: \n/usr/share/maven/bin/mvn --batch-mode -Djava.io.tmpdir=/opt/build/bamboo/bamboo-app/atlassian-bamboo/temp/RCS-ENGAGE-SERVERTEST test -Djava.io.tmpdir=/opt/build/tmp/bamboo/RCS-ENGAGE-SERVERTEST
{quote}

"test -Djava.io.tmpdir=/opt/build/tmp/bamboo/${bamboo.buildKey\}" is what I specify in the goal field, so it appears to be appending it as expected, but maven ignores the second definition of it.

I can't find a way to either remove or configure the first java.io.tmpdir property definition at the job level outside of the goal.

Expected behavior is to not have Bamboo automatically put a default java.io.tmpdir property in the maven command arguments so that one can be defined in the goal field.

h3. Workaround
As of Bamboo 6.9 maven's {{java.io.tmpdir}} property is constructed using value of system property {{bamboo.build.parent.java.io.tmpdir}} (or {{java.io.tmpdir}} if the former is not set) suffixed with a job-specific subdirectory. Thus one can use {{bamboo.build.parent.java.io.tmpdir}} system property passed to agent to affect the tmp dir location for all maven executions for a given agent.
fields.summary: maven build's java.io.tmpdir property cannot be configured or overridden

fields.description: Customers running multiple bamboo servers would find it useful if you could for example app link to another bamboo instance and share artifacts between instances in the same way they are shared between plans.
fields.summary: Allow sharing of artifacts between bamboo instances

fields.description:
When setting the Dependancies for a given plan, the list of available child plans will include the current plan (the parent).  

If selected and saved, it won't be set, but why include it on the list if its 
a no op.  My guess is that we are populating the pulldown with "all plans" with out filtering.
fields.summary: Don't list current plan when listing potential child plans

fields.description:
http://www.perforce.com/perforce/doc.current/manuals/cmdref/P4CHARSET.html

Essentially we want a text field in the advanced section of the perforce config that lets people enter the character encoding they want to use.

If the encoding is set, we add this as an environment variable (via depot.settings) to the command. If no encoding is set (field is empty), don't set the environment variable
fields.summary: Allow user to set character encoding for perforce

fields.description:
Sometimes you need to set extra params for checkout e.g. encoding
If we could set arbitrary environment variables for the checkout task, this would allow this.
fields.summary: Ability to set environment variables for checkout tasks

fields.description:
When a build succeeds (or fails), I'd like to be able to have Bamboo send a HTTP message to a URL of my own definition.

This would enable integration with services that have Webhook APIs, for instance the Slack chat app.
fields.summary: Add notification type for webhooks

fields.description:
I have an issue with a scp copy job copying artifacts to a remote system. It seems to work correctly (as in build stage creates a valid artifact, deploy stage references that artifact) but executes the actual copying of the artifact twice (one with the current version of the artifact, once with an older version of the artifact). This results in my freshly compiled and packaged application being replaced with a version from a previous build, which is a problem.)

Strangely the artifact-link is correctly offered in the bamboo webapp, It also looks fine from the file structure view of the build-stage, just when the deploy-stage begins it seems to copy the current and an old version of the artifact to the working directory and then proceeds to scp both files to the remote location.

Here is the relevant part of the log:

{noformat}
simple	24-Mar-2014 11:22:56	Starting task 'Copy WAR File to Tomcat' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-scp-plugin:scptask'
simple	24-Mar-2014 11:22:56	Connecting to host.domain.de on port: 22
simple	24-Mar-2014 11:22:56	Uploading 'D:\bamboo-home\xml-data\build-dir\260997122\PROJECT-TB-DEP\SW-0.6.5-SNAPSHOT.war' to '/home/aemat/webapps/SW.war'...
simple	24-Mar-2014 11:22:58	'D:\bamboo-home\xml-data\build-dir\260997122\PROJECT-TB-DEP\SW-0.6.5-SNAPSHOT.war' was uploaded successfully.
simple	24-Mar-2014 11:22:58	Uploading 'D:\bamboo-home\xml-data\build-dir\260997122\PROJECT-TB-DEP\SW-0.6.4-SNAPSHOT.war' to '/home/aemat/webapps/SW.war'...
simple	24-Mar-2014 11:22:59	'D:\bamboo-home\xml-data\build-dir\260997122\PROJECT-TB-DEP\SW-0.6.4-SNAPSHOT.war' was uploaded successfully.
simple	24-Mar-2014 11:22:59	Finished task 'Copy WAR File to Tomcat'
{noformat}

As you can see there are two files beeing copied to the remote server: the first file is the current product of the build, the second one is the "old", deprecated file.

please advise, what can i do, where can i look?
fields.summary: SCP Copy Task copies old files / files from previous builds

fields.description: Would it be possible to add a "No Fail" option to the undeploy task?  This happens if you don't have an application at that context (for example, the first build or a manual undeploy), but that shouldn't really be fatal since there's probably a deploy after that.  In my case I do a server restart after the undeploy to clear out the Tomcat class loaders so there's no residual leftover from the previous deployment.  Otherwise you have to go in and disable the task and then do the build and then re-enable it.
fields.summary: Tomcat undeploy task should be idempotent

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently it's not possible to filter, favorite or create a wallboard for projects in the deployment dashboard.

h3. Suggested Solution

Implement the same functionality for filtering, favoriting and creating a wallboard for deployments that exists for build plans
fields.summary: Add dashboard filters for deployment plans

fields.description:
It is not recommended to have duplicate names in LDAP and in the local user management. Now if this so happens, the groups from LDAP are overshadowed by the local groups. Effectively Bamboo is illussioned. 
*Steps to replicate*
# Create a user in local directory say "sultan"
# Associate that user to some groups say "bamboo-admin"
# Now create same user in LDAP and associate it with the group "test-group"
!ldap.png|thumbnail!
# Integrate Bamboo to use LDAP. You can have "external user management* turned on or off
# Search for that user in Bamboo

*Expected behaviour*
Bamboo should list the users duplicate, each with appropriate groups..e.g sultan --> bamboo-admin & sultan --> test-group 

*Current behaviour*
Bamboo list as duplicate but all having the same local group
!userview.png|thumbnail!

The weired thing is that in the latest Bamboo 5.4.2, it rather aggregates the group from local and ldap. See
!userviewlatest.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: membership of users with duplicate names in LDAP is overshadowed

fields.description:
Dear friends,

I had an issue on setting up my e-mail account on Bamboo and due to that I would like to share my findings with you.

h3.1. Gmail Settings - Get started with IMAP and POP3
{noformat:title=Outgoing Mail (SMTP) Server - Requires TLS}
smtp.gmail.com
Port: 465 or 587
Requires SSL: Yes
Requires authentication: Yes
Use same settings as incoming mail server
{noformat}

h3. 2. Setting up your e-mail using the Admin section
{noformat:title=Form Data from http://<bamboo-domain>/admin/saveMailServer.action}
name: Bamboo
from: <USER>@atlassian.com
prefix: [Bamboo]
checkBoxFields: removePrecedence
chosenMailSetting: SMTP
selectFields: chosenMailSetting
hostName: smtp.gmail.com
smtpPort: 465
userName: <USER>@atlassian.com
passwordChange: true
checkBoxFields: passwordChange
password: <PASSWORD>
tlsRequired: true
checkBoxFields: tlsRequired
jndiName:
testRecipient: <USER>@atlassian.com
sendTest: Test
atl_token: 9f655d50f0e8f331c5cbfc824c5b1e53f6658dc4
{noformat}

h4. 2.1. Using <smtpPort:465> and <tlsRequired:true|false> provides an error

{panel:bgColor=#f5f5f5}
(x) Could not connect to SMTP host: smtp.gmail.com, port: 465, response: -1
{panel}

h4. 2.2. Using <smtpPort:587> and <tlsRequired:true|false> email gets sent out

h3. 3. Setting up your e-mail editing <server.xml> file
{code:title=<bamboo-install>/conf/server.xml|xml}
<!--Resource name="mail/GmailSmtpServer"
           auth="Container"
           type="javax.mail.Session"
           mail.smtp.host="smtp.gmail.com"
           mail.smtp.port="465"
           mail.smtp.auth="true"
           mail.smtp.user="<USER>@atlassian.com"
           password="<PASSWORD>"
           mail.smtp.starttls.enable="true"
           mail.smtp.socketFactory.class="javax.net.ssl.SSLSocketFactory"
         /-->
{code}

{panel:bgColor=#f5f5f5}
(x) "mail.smtp.port" set as 587 does not work at all, instead, use 465
{panel}
{panel:bgColor=#f5f5f5}
"mail.smtp.auth" needs to be set as TRUE, otherwise:
(x) The mail settings you entered were not valid. Error thrown was: com.sun.mail.smtp.SMTPSendFailedException: 530-5.5.1 Authentication Required. Learn more at 530 5.5.1 http://support.google.com/mail/bin/answer.py?answer=14257 ga9sm26068813vdc.22 - gsmtp
{panel}
{panel:bgColor=#f5f5f5}
(x) "mail.smtp.starttls.enable" can be set as TRUE or FALSE and the email gets sent away with no error(s) and/or warning(s).

fields.description:
We have a number of library projects that are built with Bamboo.
When we have a project that has not yet written any tests we get a JUnit XML file that does not yet have test cases (see attached). However this causes Bamboo JUnit Parser task to fail and breaks build.

{quote} Failing task since test cases were expected but none were found.{quote}

I think that Bamboo should just report that the build has zero tests and not break the build. Once tests are added then they will be parsed and counted in future. I know that I can just disable the JUnit Parser task until tests are written but this seems like a hassle to have to remember to re-enable a task manually.
fields.summary: JUnit Parser tasks fails when project does not yet have tests

fields.description:
On nearly every page detection if user has permission to any plan is done to see if "Create->Clone an existing plan" menu should be displayed or not.

It really slows down Bamboo for normal users that have more complicated permission checking than admins.
fields.summary: Slow Bamboo page loading due to detection on every page if user has permission to any plan

fields.description:
From time to time the Bamboo server uses up all its 90 database connections and reaches some sort of dead lock. It normally happens between 2pm and 3pm Sydney time (3-4am UTC). I suspect it is releated to the daily branch deletion background job. A build expiry background job running at the same time could also have a bad effect.

So far, a restart is the only solution.
fields.summary: Bamboo uses up all database connections and becomes unresponsive

fields.description:
This bug behavior is similar to https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-12775
The issue here is that we have defined an active profile to run based on the version of the JDK as described in http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-profiles.html

Now with a single profile, the MRP fails with the error :
{code}
2014-03-17 18:30:16,045 INFO [9-BAM::Default Agent::Agent:pool-24-thread-1] [TaskExecutorImpl] TESTA-MRP0-JOB1-5: Starting task 'Maven Dependencies Processor' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.maven:task.mvn.dependencies.processor'
2014-03-17 18:30:16,045 INFO [9-BAM::Default Agent::Agent:pool-24-thread-1] [MavenDependenciesProcessorTask] Parsing maven project file D:\atlassian\BAMBOO\atlassian-bamboo-5.4.1\HOME\xml-data\build-dir\TESTA-MRP0-JOB1\pom.xml
2014-03-17 18:30:16,197 ERROR [9-BAM::Default Agent::Agent:pool-24-thread-1] [MavenDependenciesProcessorTask] TESTA-MRP0-JOB1-5: Automatic Maven plan dependencies processing failed: org.apache.maven.project.ProjectBuildingException: Some problems were encountered while processing the POMs:
[ERROR] Failed to determine Java version for profile default @ line 52, column 10
{code}
The segment of the pom.xml showing the profile:
{code:xml}
<profiles>
		<profile>
			<activation>
				<jdk>1.7</jdk>
			</activation>
			<properties>
				<jdk.compiler.version>1.7</jdk.compiler.version>
			</properties>
			<dependencies>
				<dependency>
					<groupId>javax.mail</groupId>
					<artifactId>mail</artifactId>
					<version>1.4.5</version>
				</dependency>
				<dependency>
					<groupId>javax.activation</groupId>
					<artifactId>activation</artifactId>
					<version>1.1.1</version>
				</dependency>
				<dependency>
					<groupId>org.slf4j</groupId>
					<artifactId>slf4j-log4j12</artifactId>
					<version>1.7.5</version>
				</dependency>
				<dependency> 
					<groupId>cglib</groupId>
					<artifactId>cglib</artifactId>
					<version>2.2.2</version>
				</dependency>
				<dependency>
					<groupId>joda-time</groupId>
					<artifactId>joda-time</artifactId>
					<version>2.1</version>
				</dependency>
				<dependency> 
					<groupId>org.apache.commons</groupId>
					<artifactId>commons-lang3</artifactId>
					<version>3.1</version>
				</dependency>
				<dependency>
					<groupId>org.aspectj</groupId>
					<artifactId>aspectjweaver</artifactId>
					<version>1.7.2</version>
				</dependency>
				<dependency>
					<groupId>org.apache.openejb</groupId>
					<artifactId>javaee-api</artifactId>
					<version>5.0-3</version>
					<scope>provided</scope>
				</dependency>
			</dependencies>

			<build>
				<plugins>
					<plugin>
						<artifactId>maven-jar-plugin</artifactId>
						<version>2.4</version>
						<configuration>
							<classifier>jdk7</classifier>
						</configuration>
					</plugin>
				</plugins>

			</build>
		</profile>
</profiles>
{code}

If we add multiple profiles with with an id, we get errors like:
{code}
Automatic Maven plan dependencies processing failed: org.apache.maven.project.ProjectBuildingException: Some problems were encountered while processing the POMs:[ERROR] Failed to determine Java version for profile if_jdk5 @ line 30, column 10[ERROR] Failed to determine Java version for profile if_jdk6 @ line 104, column 10
{code}

Segment in pom
{code:xml}
<profiles>
		<profile>
			<id>if_jdk5</id>
			<activation>
				<jdk>1.5</jdk>
			</activation>
			<properties>
				<jdk.compiler.version>1.5</jdk.compiler.version>
			</properties>
			<dependencies>
.
.
.
{code}

The effective poms can be generated successfully without problem and the maven task can run a build of the project

fields.description:
I'm using onDemand, and have Jira, Confluence, Bamboo, and Bitbucket active in my account.

When I create a new user in the "user management" section, that user is automatically added to all groups in my Bitbucket account. So, for example, if I have an "admin" group and a "developers" group, the new user gets added to BOTH. There seems to be no way to stop this from happening-- I can only go into the groups after the fact and delete the permission. 

This is a huge security issue-- there's no way to even deselect "Bitbucket" when I create a new user-- there are only checkboxes for Jira, Confluence, and Bamboo, so I don't even have the choice to not grant them access at all.
fields.summary: users automatically granted admin priveleges in Bitbucket

fields.description:
In [setting up plan dependencies|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Setting+up+plan+build+dependencies], when the parent and child plan uses the same repository, then Bamboo will ensure that the revision or hash number (in the case of git) cloned is same for both builds. Now the issue with SVN is that when we add a shared repo with a gloabl variable and have this overridden by plans, Bamboo still assumes the plans are using same repo.
 
*Steps to replicate*
# My repository is located in the URL: https://sultan-PC/svn/
# So I created a shared repo with the URL: https://sultan-PC/svn/${bamboo.svnpath}
!shared.png|thumbnail!
# Configure a global variable svnpath that can point to any location. In this case, it point to some other repository not intended for this test.
!global.PNG|thumbnail!
# In the parent plan, I override this variable to point to a repo
!parent.PNG|thumbnail!
# The child plan also overrides this variable to point to a different plan
!child.PNG|thumbnail!

Now we will expect that the two plans have different repositories but Bamboo assumes both to be from same repo and try to clone same revision number of the child. This will cause the child plan to always fail with the error below eventhough the variable has been substituted correctly:
{noformat}
Caused by: com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: Unable to retrieve source code for revision '11', plan 'TESTA-CSVN-JOB1': svn: E160006: No such target revision '11' found in the repository.
svn: E175002: REPORT of '/svn/mavenimport/!svn/vcc/default': 500 Internal Server Error (https://sultan-pc)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.svn.SvnRepository.retrieveSourceCode(SvnRepository.java:616)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.vcs.task.VcsCheckoutTask.fillWorkingDirFromVcs(VcsCheckoutTask.java:248)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.vcs.task.VcsCheckoutTask.access$100(VcsCheckoutTask.java:54)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.vcs.task.VcsCheckoutTask$2.call(VcsCheckoutTask.java:175)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.vcs.task.VcsCheckoutTask$2.call(VcsCheckoutTask.java:171)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.executor.RetryingTaskExecutor.rerun(RetryingTaskExecutor.java:108)
	... 12 more
Caused by: org.tmatesoft.svn.core.SVNException: svn: E160006: No such target revision '11' found in the repository.
svn: E175002: REPORT of '/svn/mavenimport/!svn/vcc/default': 500 Internal Server Error (https://sultan-pc)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.wc.SVNErrorManager.error(SVNErrorManager.java:64)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.wc.SVNErrorManager.error(SVNErrorManager.java:51)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.DAVRepository.runReport(DAVRepository.java:1289)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.DAVRepository.update(DAVRepository.java:835)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.wc2.ng.SvnNgAbstractUpdate.updateInternal(SvnNgAbstractUpdate.java:192)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.wc2.ng.SvnNgAbstractUpdate.update(SvnNgAbstractUpdate.java:76)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.wc2.ng.SvnNgUpdate.run(SvnNgUpdate.java:38)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.wc2.ng.SvnNgUpdate.run(SvnNgUpdate.java:18)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.wc2.ng.SvnNgOperationRunner.run(SvnNgOperationRunner.java:20)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.wc2.SvnOperationRunner.run(SvnOperationRunner.java:20)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.wc2.SvnOperationFactory.run(SvnOperationFactory.java:1235)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.wc2.SvnOperation.run(SvnOperation.java:291)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.wc.SVNUpdateClient.doUpdate(SVNUpdateClient.java:311)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.wc.SVNUpdateClient.doUpdate(SVNUpdateClient.java:291)
{noformat}

*Workaround*
The viable option apart from disabling the shared repos feature is to check the option "Use SVN export" option in the repository advanced config

fields.description:
Hi, currently it looks like Bamboo (5.4.1) does not support our wildly popular product HipChat Server.  
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Integrating+Bamboo+with+HipChat

A small tweak would allow Bamboo to support it (customizing the BaseURL, using api.hipchat.com as the default for most Cloud users to connect to hipchat.com)

JIRA and Confluence are both already compatible:
http://help.hipchat.com/knowledgebase/articles/309584-integrations-with-hipchat-server

We're pushing HipChat Server into open beta soon and we're using Bamboo internally and we'd like to send notifications to our dogfood deployment along with allowing our eager Beta Customers to tie together all of their Atlassian products.

Kind Regards, -John
fields.summary: Integration with HipChat Server

fields.description:
h3. Scenario: 
a plan configured with [gatekeeper auto-merging|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO053/Using+plan+branches#Usingplanbranches-Usingautomaticmerging].

h3. Symptom: 
after successfully building the feature branch, the push back to master fails with the error message "Exception during push: Can't guess branch name for revision <some_revision> when trying to perform push", where <some_revision> is a Git commit hash. Doing a {{git branch --contains}} shows that revision to only be on the gatekeeper branch, so the error message given by Bamboo doesn't make sense.

Example: https://jira-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/browse/MASTERONE-CIFUNCHAL42-101 (screenshot attached in case that build has been purged).

h3. Workaround
Go to Bamboo overview / Repository Settings / Manage caches
You should be able to locate the revision sha id that causes the "Can't guess branch name" and it should probably be in "Unused" status. Delete it and try to rebuild your plan, it should work!
fields.summary: Can't guess branch name for revision that's only on one branch

fields.description:
A situation can arise where an SVN controlled agent "workspace" will show that it has conflicts. (These may be introduced during the build process or for some other reason.) The build will log the fact there is a conflict, but rather than halt the build will continue to build with the existing content of the workspace.

Improvement would be to either raise an exception or have the build halt with an "Conflicted workspace" error or similar.

fields.description:
When a remote mail server fails, or is taken down for maintenance, Bamboo may not to time out failed SMTP connections.   These can back up the queueing process and will prevent work going out to agents.

Implementing a timeout for stale SMTP connections may be one approach.
fields.summary: Hanging failed SMTP connections prevent jobs from running

fields.description:
The company I work for has dozens of clients that we service on varying levels from passing off artifacts to managing their environments and doing all levels of deployments.

It is useful currently with the Builds section as I can create a Build Project for a client and have all their builds associated with them under there. But under deployments there is no way to group deployment projects.

Please make it possible to allow grouping of Deployment Projects.

fields.description:
When opening a task that contains a text box (text area) (Ex. SSH Task, Script task, etc.) in a new tab or new window, the text area is missing. 
Switching to a different browser doesn't make any difference. It's the same result with Chrome, Firefox and Safari.

I tested for this in Bamboo 5.3 and 5.4.2. Please check the attached screenshots. 

*Workaround:* Edit the tasks by selecting them under the plan configuration - > jobs instead of opening them in a new tab or a new window.
fields.summary: Text area is missing when opening tasks to edit in a new tab or window

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Artifact is not copying empty folders. This behavior is recent since it was working in Bamboo 5.14.1
h3. Environment

The Bamboo instances tested were running in Linux

Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a plan with two stages
 # The first stage will do the following:
 ## Create the folder structure with some files:{code}
mkdir -p a/\{b1,b2,b3}/\{c1,c2}/d
touch a/b1/test_b1
touch a/b1/c1/test_c1
{code}
 ## Create a shared artifact with the following copy pattern:
 ## {code}
**/a/**
{code}
 # The second stage will just download the artifact

h3. Expected Results

The following structure is observed:

{code}
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	.
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	├── a
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│   ├── b1
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│   │   ├── c1
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│   │   │   ├── d
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│   │   │   └── test_c1
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│   │   ├── c2
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│   │   │   └── d
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│   │   └── test_b1
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│   ├── b2
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│   │   ├── c1
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│   │   │   └── d
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│   │   └── c2
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│   │       └── d
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│   └── b3
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│       ├── c1
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│       │   └── d
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│       └── c2
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	│           └── d
{code}
h3. Actual Results

Only the folders with content are copied:
{code}
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	.
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	└── a
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	    └── b1
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	        ├── c1
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	        │   └── test_c1
17-Feb-2017 08:34:57	        └── test_b1
{code}

The same test was performed in Bamboo 5.14.1 and the whole structure is returned (Artifact definition covers the empty folders).

h3. Workaround
 # Create an artifact with the whole content that should be covered by the artifact
 # Publish this archive as the artifact
 # Download the artifact in the next stage
 # Unzip the artifact archive downloaded


Currently, when a copy pattern is defined, only files are being copied into an artifact (preserving the directory layout). 

This may cause builds to fail in case a following conditions are met:
 * empty directories are present (e.g. SVN allows to version directories)
 * build scripts depend on a presence of such directory (e.g. Ant's <fileset dir="...")
 * artifact is used to pass files between jobs

*Workaround:*

Pack artifact content into an archive, share the archive file, later unpack it in a job using it.
fields.summary: Artifact should contain empty directories if they match naming pattern

fields.description:
Would be extremely helpful and just plain logical for the "Release Version" to apply for all branches of a particular build plan.

We release from different release branches (with the JIRA ticket integration e.g. release-XPROJ-1, release-XPROJ-2).

It seems that Bamboo deployments was created with the mindset there would only be a single release branch...would that be correct?

When counting instances not controlled by server, Bamboo should ignore unrelated instances

fields.description:
While application links can be established between Bamboo and multiple Stash instances, notifications are only sent to a single default instance. 

If multiple instances are linked, either all instances should be notified by Stash notifications, or a way to specify which instance should be notified should be available when configuring the notification.
fields.summary: Notifications for multiple Stash instances

fields.description:
We have a plan ({{SOLR-LOADOFFERS}}) that consists of multiple stages and jobs, and, in addition to that has a child plan ({{SOLR-SOLRREPLICATION}}).

We ran into the issue that the child plan was not executed although the parent plan was successfully executed. It seems that the scheduled backup that is run at 1:00 AM every morning, changing the system state to {{PAUSING}}, effectively disallowing the child plan to execute.

This happened silently. There was no mentioning of a failed plan. The child plan  just didn't get executed. While I can understand to not run new jobs during a
  scheduled backup, I would think that dependent jobs are an exception.

Is this intended behavior? Is there an upgrade we can do to fix this?
fields.summary: Backups silently disallows child plan to execute

fields.description:
This bug is clone of BAM-13967,
But since the fix is not working, we raised another bug

We are using https://bamboo.atg.com/bamboo/telemetry.action?filter=labels&labelNames=abc to monitor our builds.

In Filter Projects tab, if we filter with project name (not with the label) and save it (example : xyz).

It is displaying the build plans with abc label and build plans of the project name which i have saved in filter.

i.e it is showing the build plans of abc and xyz.
Ideally it should only show abc build plans.
Here xyz is not a label, its a project name.
fields.summary: Bamboo telemetry page shows incorrect result

fields.description:
As a build engineer, I would like the set of tasks available in build plans and deployment plans to be analagous.

They may have functionality limited [like reporting, UI visualization] but they should be accessible to be executed.

As a couple examples:  

VCS Tagging / Branching tasks would be useful, in order to create a tag once something was deployed to an environment that matters to prevent tag/branch spam.  This can be done cmd line, but if the functionality already exists in bamboo... why not leverage it!

Third party plugins like the Artifactory plugin expose incredibly useful tasks to push into a repo / pull from a repo.  Both actions can be seen to be useful in the context of deployments.  (For example, A deployment pipeline that goes from Artifactory/Repo -> Test -> UAT -> Prod ... the first deployment project would deploy to artifactory, the subsequent ones would pull from the repo and deploy to servers.)
fields.summary: Allow usage of more (all?) tasks in deployment projects

fields.description:
Whenever the Bamboo server is restarted, the System Errors from the previous application session are lost. Customers also have to periodically check whether there are System Errors occurring by visiting {{Bamboo Administration > System > System errors}} instead of being notified (by email).

The list of System Errors could be available as an RSS feed. It would be beneficial on both persisting the problem report of an error beyond the current application session and pushing notifications to administrators when they occur.

Also, System Errors could notify system administrators by email.
fields.summary: Notifications for System Errors

fields.description:
To recreate this problem (Windows):
Create a workspace (we use Perforce) and a Plan that uses it. Then create an INLINE script job task that contains one line of code:

echo Hello, World!

Set the task's working directory to c:\bin .

When your plan runs, you'll get an error just like this one:

Beginning to execute external process for build 'REL TEST - Run Batch file #109 (RELTEST-BATCHTESTBUILD-109)'\n ... running command line:

\nD:\tmp\RELTEST-BATCHESTBUILD-109-ScriptBuildTask-4410225451194361740.bat\n ... in: d:\views\BatchTest\c:\bin\n ... using extra environment variables: \nbamboo_TESTPROJECT=BatchTest_v01\n

Failing task since return code of [D:\tmp\RELTEST-BATCHESTBUILD-109-ScriptBuildTask-4410225451194361740.bat] was -1 while expected 0

The batch file will NEVER execute because the explicit full path of the working directory was concatenated with the workspace directory info from the repository.

This also happens if the script is a file instead of inline, and appears to also occur if the script is called as a Command task using cmd.exe /c scriptname.bat .

We are currently crafting a miserable & loopy workaround for this problem and hope you can fix the issue soon.
fields.summary: Batch scripts execute in incorrect working directory if supplied directory is outside of src control workspace

fields.description:
*Problem Description*
If you have over 25 Shared artifacts in a single Bamboo plan, when you want to configure *Artifact Download* task inside your Deployment or build project, the list caps out at 25 entries

*Steps to replicate*
# Make sure you have around at least 30 Shared Artifacts
# Configure your Deployment or Build project and on adding task on the environment choose *Artifact Download* task
# Check the available shared artifact under _Artifact Name_ field
# Click *Add another artifact* button on the task configuration
# Check again the available shared artifact under _Artifact Name_ field and you notice every artifact past the 25 count is missing

*Workaround*
- Save the *Artifact Download Task* (Initial view before saving and recreating: https://www.dropbox.com/s/de9k5jys4zhqk59/Screenshot%202014-12-09%2017.21.33.png)
- Edit the task again
- See that more than 25 are present (https://www.dropbox.com/s/qvti8pctx7oflhq/Screenshot%202014-12-09%2017.21.53.png)
fields.summary: Unable to retrieve all shared artifacts in Download artifact task in Deployment or Build

fields.description:
*Problem Description*
If the Deployment project was pointed to the branch instead of the master or trunk of the plan, somehow you can't choose the shared artifact inside *Artifact Download* task when you configure the environment of Deployment.

*Steps to replicate*
# Make sure you have Shared Artifact on branch enabled plan
# Point the deployment project to Master/Trunk of the Plan
# Configure the environment's task of that Deployment project
# Choose the Artifact Download task and notice the Shared Artifact list will appear
# Edit the Deployment project and point it to any of the branch instead
# Edit the environment task again
# On the Artifact Download task, you will notice that the Shared Artifact list is missing
fields.summary: Unable to select shared artifact when Deployment is linked to branch of the plan

fields.description:
As of today Bamboo variables are only single (key, value) pairs. If one wants to define Parametrized Plans, it implies to remember all options in order to run the customized builds. This is quite error prone or leads to the duplication of plans to go around this issue.

Enabling the definition of list type variables would solve this situation.

Features:
#1 When running a customized plan, the user would be presented with the drop down with the list of values for the parameter
#2 The list of values would be available from the REST API (/plan/\{projectKey\}-\{buildKey\}?expand=variableContext)
#3 Possibility to define the default value
fields.summary: Enable the definition of list type variables

fields.description:
- Install Windows Server 2012
- Add .NET 3.5 in features and roles
- Install Visual Studio 2013
- Install a brand new version of Bamboo  5.4.1.
- Visit the bamboo administration page
- select "server capabilities"
- observe that MSBuild is not in the capabilities list.
- select "Detect server capabilities"
- observe that none of the MSBuild executables are detected.

In reality, there are several versions of MSBuild already installed as part of .NET

- C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v2.0.50727\msbuild.exe
- C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v3.5\msbuild.exe
- C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\msbuild.exe
- C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework64\v2.0.50727\msbuild.exe
- C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework64\v3.5\msbuild.exe
- C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework64\v4.0.30319\msbuild.exe

With Visual Studio 2013, msbuild is located at 

C:\Program Files (x86)\MSBuild\12.0\Bin\msbuild.exe
C:\Program Files (x86)\MSBuild\12.0\Bin\amd64\msbuild.exe

I'm expecting that Bamboo will automatically find the msbuild versions and register them.
fields.summary: MSBuild not detected

fields.description:
s3tools.org appears to be down for the time being. The ami-430a452a instances that come up have a yum reference to it:

{quote}
[root@ip-10-36-14-182 tmp]# cat /etc/yum.repos.d/s3tools.repo
#
# Save this file to /etc/yum.repos.d on your system
# and run "yum install s3cmd"
#
[s3tools]
name=Tools for managing Amazon S3 - Simple Storage Service (RHEL_6)
type=rpm-md
baseurl=http://s3tools.org/repo/RHEL_6/
gpgcheck=1
gpgkey=http://s3tools.org/repo/RHEL_6/repodata/repomd.xml.key
enabled=1
{quote}

that was made when the AMI was snapshot'd months ago:

{quote}
[root@ip-10-36-14-182 tmp]# stat /etc/yum.repos.d/s3tools.repo
  File: `/etc/yum.repos.d/s3tools.repo'
  Size: 301             Blocks: 8          IO Block: 4096   regular file
Device: ca01h/51713d    Inode: 132001      Links: 1
Access: (0644/-rw-r--r--)  Uid: (    0/    root)   Gid: (    0/    root)
Access: 2013-09-03 14:08:58.000000000 +0000
Modify: 2011-01-09 22:16:55.000000000 +0000
Change: 2013-09-03 14:08:58.254441362 +0000
{quote}

The result is that if you run a script that includes "set -e" && "yum update" an agent will not fully deploy, instead failing like this:

{quote}
http://s3tools.org/repo/RHEL_6/repodata/repomd.xml: [Errno 14] PYCURL ERROR 7 - "Failed to connect to 2a01:348:0:6:5d59:50c3:0:b0b1: Network is unreachable"
Trying other mirror.
Error: Cannot retrieve repository metadata (repomd.xml) for repository: s3tools. Please verify its path and try again
{quote}

Our workaround for the time being is adding 
{quote}
rm -f /etc/yum.repos.d/s3tools.repo
yum update
{quote}

I recommend deprecating usage of s3cmd for amazons authored python lib: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/awscli
fields.summary: Bamboo instances failing on ami-430a452a due to s3tools.org being down

fields.summary: Webhook notification type

fields.description:
According to this REST page:
https://developer.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOODEV/Using+the+Bamboo+REST+APIs

You should be able to login to REST via a URL request by using the following scheme:
"http://host:8085/rest/api/latest/plan?os_authType=basic&os_username=<user>&os_password=<pw>"

This worked fine for us before we upgraded to 5.4.1. After we upgraded, this request would produce a 403 Unauthorized Access error. We noticed the XSRF setting and tried disabling the protection. After the protection was disabled, the same URL request worked.

Our bamboo instance runs in a private environment so this does not pose any immediate risk to us, but it doesn't appear to be the intended behavior. Is the intention to obsolete the basic URL authorization? If so, the above page should be updated.
fields.summary: XSRF Protection Disables Basic URL Rest Authorization

fields.description:
*Problem Description*
When there's some issue with the shared repository cache, Build admin will try to delete the cache repository as the first step. However when the XSRF protection is enabled, it will throw an exception.
{noformat}
java.lang.IllegalStateException: XSRF: Cannot delete caches
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.utils.XsrfUtils.fail(XsrfUtils.java:20)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.utils.XsrfUtils.assertCanPerformMutativeAction(XsrfUtils.java:40)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.actions.admin.RepositorySettingsAction.doDelete(RepositorySettingsAction.java:78)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:57)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	...
{noformat}

*Steps to replicate*
# Set up a shared repository in Bamboo through _Bamboo Admin >> Shared Repository_.
# Set up a plan with that shared repository, and run a checkout task.
# Make sure the *XSRF Protection* is enabled from _Bamboo Admin >> Security Settings_.
# Delete the repository cache from _Bamboo Admin >> Repository Settings_
fields.summary: Deleting Shared repository cache will throw an exception if XSRF protection is enabled
